comments:
Legal Studies 210 explores business responsibility from rival theoretical and managerial perspectives. Its focus includes theories of ethics and their application to case studies in business. Topics include moral issues in advertising and sales; hiring and promotion; financial management; corporate pollution; product safety; and decision-making across borders and cultures. 

The course syllabus has a few key cases that Dr. Radin always covers, but she tends to let student discussion and interest guide the topics and how much time is spent covering them. Most students love the class and many suggest that corporate ethics “should be a requirement.” 

Students tend to either love or hate Dr. Radin’s teaching style. Many find her “fabulous” and “inspiring,” and appreciate the way that she makes herself available to “listen and help students” on anything from classroom topics to personal matters. Others point out that she can be “very stubborn in her own opinions” or “preachy.”

This class is not for students who rarely speak up in class. With 45% of the grade coming from participation and some students suggesting that “she tends to call on the same people most of the time” it can be hard for less aggressive students to get heard. Nearly everyone complained in one way or another about the grading system, most often pointing out that “there is no feedback to understand how you are doing in class” and worrying that “favoritism is reflected into the grades.”

Legal Studies 210 explores business responsibility from rival theoretical and managerial perspectives. Its focus includes theories of ethics and their application to case studies in business. Topics include moral issues in advertising and sales; hiring and promotion; financial management; corporate pollution; product safety; and decision-making across borders and cultures. 

“The Professor did an excellent job making topics and issues applicable to us,” reported one student. Many appreciated how the class got them to think about other perspectives outside the law or their own beliefs. 

Students found Professor Sarachan to be “awesome,” “thoughtful,” and “considerate,” “one of the best professors I’ve ever had.” Students particularly valued how “he never acts as if anything a student says is unimportant or wrong,” especially given the focus on student discussion. Others also appreciated his ability “to get every student to actively participate without resorting to cold calling.”

Legal Studies 210 explores business responsibility from rival theoretical and managerial perspectives. Its focus includes theories of ethics and their application to case studies in business. Topics include moral issues in advertising and sales; hiring and promotion; financial management; corporate pollution; product safety; and decision-making across borders and cultures. 

While students loved the material covered in Professor Strudler’s class, some felt that the format was “a little disjointed” and didn’t really come together until the debates at the end of the class. 

Despite issues with the format, Professor Strudler was extremely popular with his students; not only was he “very responsive to students,” but in the words of one was “the most interesting, honest, and helpful professor I’ve had.” 

Students said that the course load for LGST210 was “just right – not burdensome yet kept us interested.” A suggestion for future classes was that the final paper deadline be moved up, since it was a large part of the class grade and students were unable to get feedback on it.

Legal Studies 210 explores business responsibility from rival theoretical and managerial perspectives. Its focus includes theories of ethics and their application to case studies in business. Topics include moral issues in advertising and sales; hiring and promotion; financial management; corporate pollution; product safety; and decision-making across borders and cultures. 

This was Professor Sepinwall’s first semester teaching LGST210, and students who had a familiarity with the way other sections are taught lamented her “reliance on lecture slides rather than class discussion” and thought she could have been more familiar with the material. 

As a person, students’ appreciated Professor Sepinwall’s efforts to “be thorough and explain further any concepts” as well as to “take student input very seriously.” Those who faulted her inexperience did agree that “she will surely get better as she continues to teach the class.” 

As is common in many sections of LGST210, some students complained that “grading was arbitrary.”
